contentrichtext.text: {{Infobox scientist |name = John Canton |image = John Canton from NPG.jpg |image_size = 200px |caption = John Canton |birth_date = 31 July 1718 |birth_place = [[Stroud, Gloucestershire|Stroud]], [[Gloucestershire]] |death_date = 22 March 1772 |death_place = |residence = |citizenship = |nationality = [[England|English]] |ethnicity = |field = [[Physics]] |work_institutions = |alma_mater = |doctoral_advisor = |doctoral_students = |known_for = Artificial [[magnet]]s <br /> Compressibility of liquids |author_abbrev_bot = |author_abbrev_zoo = |influences = |influenced = |prizes = [[Copley Medal]] |religion = |footnotes = |signature = }}'''John Canton''' [[Fellow of the Royal Society|FRS]] (31 July 1718 – 22 March 1772) was an [[England|English]] [[physicist]]. Canton was born in Middle Street [[Stroud, Gloucestershire|Stroud]], [[Gloucestershire]], the son of a weaver John Canton (b. 1687) and Esther (nÃ©e Davis). At the age of nineteen, under the auspices of Dr Henry Miles, he was articled for five years as clerk to Samuel Watkins, the master of a school in Spital Square, London, with whom at the end of that time he entered into partnership.. [[File:John canton.jpg|thumb|left|150px|Plaque to John Canton on the wall of the Old Town Hall in the Shambles, [[Stroud]], [[Gloucestershire]] ]] In 1750 he read a paper before the [[Royal Society]] on a method of making artificial [[magnet]]s, which procured him election as a fellow of the society and the award of the [[Copley Medal]]. He was the first in England to verify [[Benjamin Franklin]]'s hypothesis of the identity of [[lightning]] and [[electricity]], and he made several important electrical discoveries. In 1762 and 1764 he published experiments in refutation of the decision of the [[Florentine Academy]], at that time generally accepted, that [[water]] is incompressible.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Canton, John | title = Experiments to Prove That Water is Not Incompressible | journal = Philosophical Transactions (1683-1775) | year = 1761-1762 | volume = 52 | pages = 640–643 | jstor = 105681}} </ref><ref>{{cite journal | author = Canton, John | title = Experiments and Observations on the Compressibility of Water and Some Other Fluids | journal = Philosophical Transactions (1683-1775) | year = 1764 | volume = 54 | jstor = 105560 | pages = 261–262 | doi = 10.1098/rstl.1764.0045}}</ref> In 1768 he described the preparation, by calcining oyster-shell with [[sulfur|sulphur]], of the [[phosphorescent]] material known as [http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Canton%27s_phosphorus Canton's phosphorus].<ref>{{cite journal | author = Canton, John | title = An Easy Method of Making a Phosphorus, That Will Imbibe and Emit Light, like the Bolognian Stone | journal = Philosophical Transactions (1683-1775) | volume = 58 | year = 1768 | pages =337–344 | jstor = 105793 | doi = 10.1098/rstl.1768.0045}}</ref> His investigations were carried on without any intermission of his work as a schoolmaster. He died in London aged 53 of [[dropsy]].
